history.content:
It depends on both the types of places you're applying as well as the specific role you're interested in. For example, my final round at Optiver was all market making games with a flavor of probability whereas my final rounds at purely systematic shops have consisted of manipulating Gaussian expressions/covariance matrices to prove things.

EECS126 is a must if you're doing research/trading because probability is the dominant skill selected for in the process. CS189/EECS127 help a little bit for trading, but they really help for research. 

For SWE, CS162 would be ideal for low latency, close to the metal firms that will ask you low latency questions.

I wouldn't expect classes alone to suffice however. You should do as much practice as possible and scour the internet for past questions.

children.subject:
Data100 and CS188 use probability as a tool occasionally, but it's nowhere near the level of rigor/focus as 126. 

The 2nd half of the 126 syllabus (available on the website) isn't touched by STAT134 but the 1st half would be fairly redundant.

That said, the HW problems are fantastic for 126, and taking hard classes/seeing the material again is always helpful.
for eecs 126, if ive already done stat 134, data 100, 70, and 188, looking at it, isn't there a lot of overlap?

<md>For SWE: 152, 162, 164, 168, 194-15. Note that in particular 162 and 164 do not go sufficiently deep for the most difficult firms' interviews (e.g. HRT) so you will need to supplement your understanding e.g. by reading docs on the Linux kernel and modern CPU architecture. And obviously Leetcode too.</md>

history.content: So, I currently have interned at FAANG, so I am considering going for an internship at a quant firm for next summer(summer 2023) to get a taste of both to decide for full time. Though, I'm very new to this type of interview, FAANG+similar places is leetcode/hackerrank studying typically after I took 61b/170. What's the equivalent to leetcode+61b for internships at quant firms?
history.subject: Classes for quant firm interviews?
